Decentralized MIMO Systems with LMMSE Receivers and Imperfect CSI

Zeyan Zhuang, Xin Zhang, Dongfang Xu, Shenghui Song, Senior Member, IEEE, and Yonina C. Eldar, Fellow, IEEE
(April 2024)
Abstract

Centralized baseband processing (CBP) is required to achieve the full potential of massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. However, due to the large number of antennas, CBP suffers from two major issues: 1) Tremendous data interconnection between radio frequency (RF) circuitry and processing fabrics; and 2) high-dimensional computation. To this end, decentralized baseband processing (DBP) has been proposed, where the antennas at the BS are partitioned into clusters connected to separate RF circuits and equipped with separate computing units. Unfortunately, due to the decentralized structure, the optimal fusion scheme and performance analysis for DBP with general spatial correlation between clusters and imperfect channel state information (CSI) are not available in the literature. In this paper, we consider a decentralized MIMO system where all clusters adopt linear minimum mean-square error (LMMSE) receivers with imperfect CSI. Specifically, we first establish the optimal linear fusion scheme which has high computational and data input/output (I/O) costs. To reduce the costs, we further propose two sub-optimal fusion schemes with reduced complexity. For all three schemes, we derive the closed-form expressions for the signal-to-interference-and-noise ratio (SINR) by leveraging random matrix theory (RMT) and demonstrate the conditions under which the sub-optimal schemes are optimal. Furthermore, we determine the optimal regularization parameter for decentralized LMMSE receivers, identify the best antenna partitioning strategy, and prove that the SINR will decrease as the number of clusters increases. Numerical simulations validate the accuracy of the theoretical results.

Index Terms:
decentralized baseband processing (DBP), massive multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO), linear minimum mean-square error (LMMSE), random matrix theory (RMT).

I Introduction

Massive multi-input-multi-output (MIMO) technology has been shown very effective in achieving high spectral efficiency, energy efficiency, and link reliability [1]. However, conventional implementations require centralized baseband processing (CBP) where all baseband data are collected and processed by a centralized baseband processing unit (BBU) [2, 3]. Such centralized processing will cause significant challenges when the size of the antenna arrays becomes extremely large. On the one hand, transmitting baseband data from a large number of BS antennas to the BBU will result in very high throughput demands. On the other hand, traditional detection or beamforming algorithms require the inversion of high-dimensional matrices, which causes heightened computational complexity. These challenges make CBP very difficult to implement in practice [4, 5].

To address the bandwidth and computing bottlenecks of CBP, a more efficient architecture called decentralized baseband processing (DBP) was recently proposed [6, 4, 7, 2, 8]. With DBP, BS antennas are divided into several clusters, each equipped with its own local computing fabric that performs signal processing tasks in a parallel and decentralized manner. Some engaging results have been achieved for both performance analysis and system design of the DBP architecture. In particular, Li et al. [6, 4] developed iterative decentralized detection algorithms to minimize the mean squared error (MSE) of the received symbols. A gradient descent based decentralized algorithm was proposed in [7] to obtain zero-forcing (ZF) equalization for a daisy chain architecture. In [2, 9], the feedforward DBP architecture was proposed to reduce the latency by avoiding the information exchange between clusters required by previous works [10].

With the feedforward structure, the detection results from all clusters and some middle-stage information are transferred to and fused at the central unit (CU). As a result, the fusion algorithm at the CU is very crucial for successful detection. In [2], Jeon et al. provided the optimal linear fusion that maximizes the signal-to-interference-and-noise ratio (SINR) in uncorrelated Rayleigh channels with perfect channel state information (CSI). The closed-form deterministic approximations of the SINR for maximum ratio combining (MRC), ZF, and linear minimum mean-square error (LMMSE) receivers were also derived. The design of the fusion coefficients for decentralized MIMO systems resembles that of the collaboration among access points (APs) in cell-free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) systems, where distributed APs are deployed and linked to a central processing unit (CPU) [11]. The difference between DBP and CF-mMIMO lies in the spatial correlation between different clusters, which makes the DBP architecture more general. In [12], four levels of minimum mean-square error (MMSE) receiver cooperation for CF-mMIMO systems were proposed with spatially correlated fading and imperfect CSI. However, the fusion scheme and performance analysis for DBP with general spatial correlation and imperfect CSI are not available in the literature.

In this paper, we consider the feedforward decentralized massive MIMO systems with LMMSE receivers because of their near-optimal performance and ease of implementation [10]. Furthermore, we will consider the case with imperfect CSI, due to the difficulty in obtaining perfect CSI in massive MIMO systems [13, 14]. Specifically, we first determine the optimal linear fusion for the concerned system, which requires global CSI and has high complexity. To reduce the cost, we propose two linear fusion schemes with reduced computation and communication workloads. In particular, the first scheme utilizes a moderate amount of intermediate results computed by the clusters, while the second scheme can be implemented by a fully decentralized (FD) architecture [2], where the CU only needs to calculate the weighted sum of the local detection results, without requiring any other intermediate results.

We then evaluate the performance of the proposed linear fusion schemes. Unfortunately, the presence of channel estimation (CE) errors and the decentralized structure make it very challenging to analyze the receive SINR. To this end, we adopt the large random matrix theory (RMT), which has been proven effective in analyzing the fundamental limits of centralized LMMSE receivers [15, 16]. In fact, the SINR analysis for the DBP architecture in [2] also relied on RMT, but assumed perfect CSI and uncorrelated Rayleigh channel. In this paper, we analyze the decentralized massive MIMO system with more general settings, which takes the analysis in [15, 16, 2] as special cases. Based on the analysis results, we further investigate the impacts of several key system parameters, including the regularization parameter, the antenna partitioning strategy, and the number of clusters.

The main contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • 1)

    For the concerned decentralized massive MIMO systems, we first derive the optimal linear fusion scheme to maximize the SINR and demonstrate that the optimal coefficients also minimize the MSE for estimating the transmit signal.

  • 2)

    Given the optimal fusion scheme requires global CSI and has high complexity, we propose two sub-optimal fusion schemes that only require local CSI and have reduced levels of complexity.

  • 3)

    We derive the deterministic approximations of the SINR for all three fusion schemes by RMT. The analysis results reveal that, without spatial correlation between clusters or CE errors, the first sub-optimal fusion scheme achieves the optimal performance. Moreover, the second sub-optimal fusion scheme can achieve the optimal performance when there is no spatial correlation between clusters.

  • 4)

    To obtain more physical insights, we derive the closed-form expressions for the SINR over independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) channels. Based on the results, we further determine the optimal regularization parameters and optimal antenna partition strategies that maximize SINR, and evaluate the impact of the number of clusters.

  • 5)

    From the RMT perspective, we derive the deterministic approximations for linear functions of the resolvent for covariance matrices with generally correlated columns, and demonstrate the convergence rates of the means are 𝒪​(N−12)𝒪superscript𝑁12{\mathcal{O}}(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}). These findings can be applied to the analysis of regularized zero-forcing (RZF) precoding in the downlink MIMO systems [17].

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the system model and the DBP architecture. In Section III, we prove the optimal linear fusion scheme and propose two linear fusion schemes for decentralized implementation. In Section IV, we derive the deterministic approximations for the SINR of proposed fusion schemes and investigate the results with i.i.d. channels. Numerical results are given in Section V and Section VI concludes the paper.

II System Model

II-A Signal Model

Consider an uplink MIMO system where M+1𝑀1M+1 single-antenna users transmit signals to one BS with N𝑁N antennas. We denote the transmit signal of all users as 𝕩=[x0,…,xM]T∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,𝕀M+1)𝕩superscriptsubscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑀𝑇similar-to𝒞𝒩0subscript𝕀𝑀1{\mathbb{x}}=[x_{0},\ldots,x_{M}]^{T}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,{\mathbb{I}}_{M+1}), where xjsubscript𝑥𝑗x_{j} represents the signal of user j𝑗j. The channel between user j𝑗j and the BS is denoted by 𝕙j∈ℂNsubscript𝕙𝑗superscriptℂ𝑁{\mathbb{h}}_{j}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}. Thus, the received signal at BS is given by

𝕪=Σ​𝕩+𝕟,𝕪double-struck-Σ𝕩𝕟{\mathbb{y}}=\mathbb{\Sigma}{\mathbb{x}}+{\mathbb{n}}, (1)

where 𝕪∈ℂN𝕪superscriptℂ𝑁{\mathbb{y}}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}, Σ=[𝕙0,…,𝕙M]∈ℂN×(M+1)double-struck-Σsubscript𝕙0…subscript𝕙𝑀superscriptℂ𝑁𝑀1\mathbb{\Sigma}=[{\mathbb{h}}_{0},\ldots,{\mathbb{h}}_{M}]\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times(M+1)}, and 𝕟∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,σ2​𝕀N)similar-to𝕟𝒞𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑁{\mathbb{n}}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma^{2}{\mathbb{I}}_{N}) denotes the additive Gaussian white noise (AWGN) at the BS.

Decentralized Architecture: In this paper, we consider the decentralized architecture [2, 4] as shown in Fig. 1, where the N𝑁N antennas of the BS are divided into K𝐾K clusters, connected to one CU. The k𝑘k-th cluster consists of Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} antennas, and each cluster contains its own RF components and computing fabrics. For simplicity, we partition the received signal 𝕪=[𝕪1T,…,𝕪KT]T𝕪superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝕪1𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝕪𝐾𝑇𝑇{\mathbb{y}}=[{\mathbb{y}}_{1}^{T},\ldots,{\mathbb{y}}_{K}^{T}]^{T}, the channel matrix Σ=[Σ1T,…,ΣKT]Tdouble-struck-Σsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptdouble-struck-Σ1𝑇…superscriptsubscriptdouble-struck-Σ𝐾𝑇𝑇\mathbb{\Sigma}=[\mathbb{\Sigma}_{1}^{T},\ldots,\mathbb{\Sigma}_{K}^{T}]^{T}, the channel vector 𝕙j=[𝕙j​1T,…,𝕙j​KT]T,j∈[M]0formulae-sequencesubscript𝕙𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝕙𝑗1𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝕙𝑗𝐾𝑇𝑇𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0{\mathbb{h}}_{j}=[{\mathbb{h}}_{j1}^{T},\ldots,{\mathbb{h}}_{jK}^{T}]^{T},j\in[M]_{0}, and the noise vector 𝕟=[𝕟1T,…,𝕟KT]T𝕟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝕟1𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝕟𝐾𝑇𝑇{\mathbb{n}}=[{\mathbb{n}}_{1}^{T},\ldots,{\mathbb{n}}_{K}^{T}]^{T}, such that the received signal at the k𝑘k-th cluster is given by

𝕪k=Σk​𝕩+𝕟k,k∈[K],formulae-sequencesubscript𝕪𝑘subscriptdouble-struck-Σ𝑘𝕩subscript𝕟𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝐾{\mathbb{y}}_{k}=\mathbb{\Sigma}_{k}{\mathbb{x}}+{\mathbb{n}}_{k},~{}k\in[K], (2)

with 𝕪k∈ℂNksubscript𝕪𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑁𝑘{\mathbb{y}}_{k}\in\mathbb{C}^{N_{k}}, Σk∈ℂNk×(M+1)subscriptdouble-struck-Σ𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑁𝑘𝑀1\mathbb{\Sigma}_{k}\in\mathbb{C}^{N_{k}\times(M+1)}, and 𝕟k∈ℂNksubscript𝕟𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑁𝑘{\mathbb{n}}_{k}\in\mathbb{C}^{N_{k}}. To detect the signal from user j𝑗j, cluster k𝑘k independently processes the baseband data to compute the estimate x^j​ksubscript^𝑥𝑗𝑘\widehat{x}_{jk}. The local estimate x^j​ksubscript^𝑥𝑗𝑘\widehat{x}_{jk} and a moderate amount of intermediate results are then transferred to the CU. These intermediate results are designed based on the detection scheme and typically include the Gram matrices of the channels[18, 19] or variances of the estimation errors [2]. The CU will obtain the final estimate x^jsubscript^𝑥𝑗\widehat{x}_{j} through linear fusion as

x^j=∑k=1Kαk​x^j​k,subscript^𝑥𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript^𝑥𝑗𝑘\widehat{x}_{j}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\widehat{x}_{jk}, (3)

where αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} represents the fusion coefficient that can be chosen as constant or determined based on the information from clusters. With CBP, the optimal detector is the maximum likelihood detector, which is nonlinear and computationally complex. To reduce the complexity, LMMSE detection is widely used due to its simplicity in implementation and near-optimal performance [10]. Therefore, we consider the case where all clusters adopt LMMSE detection and the detailed design schemes will be discussed in Section III.

II-B Channel Model

Due to limited angular spread and insufficient antenna spacing, spatial correlation between BS antennas is inevitable. In this paper, we consider the Rayleigh channel model [20, 21]

𝕙j=ℝj12​𝕫j,j∈[M]0,formulae-sequencesubscript𝕙𝑗superscriptsubscriptℝ𝑗12subscript𝕫𝑗𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0{\mathbb{h}}_{j}={\mathbb{R}}_{j}^{\frac{1}{2}}{\mathbb{z}}_{j},~{}j\in[M]_{0}, (4)

where ℝj∈ℂN×Nsubscriptℝ𝑗superscriptℂ𝑁𝑁{\mathbb{R}}_{j}\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times N} is a nonnegative definite matrix that models the spatial correlation of the BS antennas with respect to (w.r.t.) user j𝑗j and 𝕫j∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,𝕀N)similar-tosubscript𝕫𝑗𝒞𝒩0subscript𝕀𝑁{\mathbb{z}}_{j}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,{\mathbb{I}}_{N}). Note that this model takes the variance profile model [15, 22] as a special case. With DBP, each cluster k𝑘k can only know its local spatial correlation matrix, which is a principal submatrix of ℝjsubscriptℝ𝑗{\mathbb{R}}_{j}. To this end, we denote the index vector

𝝇k=[∑i=1k−1Ni+1,∑i=1k−1Ni+2,…,∑i=1kNi]T,k∈[K],formulae-sequencesubscript𝝇𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝑁𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝑁𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝑁𝑖𝑇𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\bm{\varsigma}_{k}=\left[\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}N_{i}+1,\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}N_{i}+2,\ldots,\sum_{i=1}^{k}N_{i}\right]^{T},~{}k\in[K], (5)

and for a N𝑁N-by-N𝑁N matrix ℝℝ{\mathbb{R}}, we define

[ℝ][k,l]=ℝ​[𝝇k,𝝇l].subscriptdelimited-[]ℝ𝑘𝑙ℝsubscript𝝇𝑘subscript𝝇𝑙[{\mathbb{R}}]_{[k,l]}={\mathbb{R}}[\bm{\varsigma}_{k},\bm{\varsigma}_{l}]. (6)

As a result, the spatial correlation of the k𝑘k-th cluster is denoted by [ℝj][k,k]subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptℝ𝑗𝑘𝑘[{\mathbb{R}}_{j}]_{[k,k]}.

Decentralized Channel Estimation: To obtain the CSI, user j𝑗j will transmit its pilot signal that is orthogonal to those of other users. The k𝑘k-th cluster estimates its local channel vector 𝕙j​ksubscript𝕙𝑗𝑘{\mathbb{h}}_{jk} based on the observation 𝕪~j​k∈ℂNksubscript~𝕪𝑗𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑁𝑘\widetilde{{\mathbb{y}}}_{jk}\in\mathbb{C}^{N_{k}}, given by [23]

For ease of illustration, we absorb the pilot transmit power and the pilot sequence length into the training SNR 1σ~21superscript~𝜎2\frac{1}{\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}}. Moreover, the training SNR is assumed known at each cluster. Under such circumstances, the MMSE estimate 𝕙^j​ksubscript^𝕙𝑗𝑘\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{jk} of 𝕙j​ksubscript𝕙𝑗𝑘{\mathbb{h}}_{jk} is given by [24]

where 𝕋j=ℝj​(σ~2​𝕀N+ℝj)−1subscript𝕋𝑗subscriptℝ𝑗superscriptsuperscript~𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑁subscriptℝ𝑗1{\mathbb{T}}_{j}={{\mathbb{R}}_{j}}(\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}{\mathbb{I}}_{N}+{{\mathbb{R}}_{j}})^{-1}, 𝔻R,j=diag​([ℝj][k,k];k∈[K])subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗diagsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptℝ𝑗𝑘𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝐾{\mathbb{D}}_{R,j}=\mathrm{diag}([{\mathbb{R}}_{j}]_{[k,k]};k\in[K]), and 𝔻T,j=𝔻R,j​(σ~2​𝕀N+𝔻R,j)−1subscript𝔻𝑇𝑗subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗superscriptsuperscript~𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑁subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗1{\mathbb{D}}_{T,j}={\mathbb{D}}_{R,j}(\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}{\mathbb{I}}_{N}+{\mathbb{D}}_{R,j})^{-1}. When the spatial correlation between antennas of different clusters is negligible, i.e., ℝj=𝔻R,jsubscriptℝ𝑗subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗{\mathbb{R}}_{j}={\mathbb{D}}_{R,j} and 𝕍jsubscript𝕍𝑗{\mathbb{V}}_{j} = 𝕀Nsubscript𝕀𝑁{\mathbb{I}}_{N}, 𝕙^jsubscript^𝕙𝑗\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{j} is the same as that estimated by the centralized MMSE estimator. Therefore, 𝕍jsubscript𝕍𝑗{\mathbb{V}}_{j} represents the effect of decentralized CE. For ease of notations, we define Σ^=[𝕙^0,…,𝕙^M]^double-struck-Σsubscript^𝕙0…subscript^𝕙𝑀\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}=[\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{0},\ldots,\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{M}], Σ^k=[𝕙^0​k,…,𝕙^M​k]subscript^double-struck-Σ𝑘subscript^𝕙0𝑘…subscript^𝕙𝑀𝑘\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}_{k}=[\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{0k},\ldots,\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{Mk}], 𝕙~j=𝕍j​𝕙^jsubscript~𝕙𝑗subscript𝕍𝑗subscript^𝕙𝑗\widetilde{{\mathbb{h}}}_{j}={\mathbb{V}}_{j}\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}_{j}, Σ~=[𝕙~0,…,𝕙~M]~double-struck-Σsubscript~𝕙0…subscript~𝕙𝑀\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}}=[\widetilde{{\mathbb{h}}}_{0},\ldots,\widetilde{{\mathbb{h}}}_{M}], and 𝕎=∑j∈[M]0𝕎j𝕎subscript𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0subscript𝕎𝑗{\mathbb{W}}=\sum_{j\in[M]_{0}}{\mathbb{W}}_{j}.

III Decentralized LMMSE Receiver and Linear Fusion

In this section, we first introduce the decentralized LMMSE receiver, and derive the optimal linear fusion scheme which requires global CSI and has high complexity. Then, we propose two linear fusion schemes, which only require local CSI and have reduced complexity.

III-A Decentralized LMMSE Receiver

Without loss of generality, we consider the detection of x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}. In particular, the k𝑘k-th cluster will utilize 𝕣ksubscript𝕣𝑘{\mathbb{r}}_{k} to obtain the estimate x^0​k=𝕣kH​𝕪ksubscript^𝑥0𝑘superscriptsubscript𝕣𝑘𝐻subscript𝕪𝑘\widehat{x}_{0k}={\mathbb{r}}_{k}^{H}{\mathbb{y}}_{k} that minimizes the local MSE

MSEk=𝔼𝕩,𝕟​|x^0​k−x0|2.subscriptMSE𝑘subscript𝔼𝕩𝕟superscriptsubscript^𝑥0𝑘subscript𝑥02\mathrm{MSE}_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{{\mathbb{x}},{\mathbb{n}}}|\widehat{x}_{0k}-x_{0}|^{2}. (11)

In the presence of CE errors, the local MSE should be calculated by taking the average over the posterior distribution Σk|Σ^kconditionalsubscriptdouble-struck-Σ𝑘subscript^double-struck-Σ𝑘\mathbb{\Sigma}_{k}|\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}_{k} [26], which yields

MSEk|Σ^k=𝔼Σk|Σ^k,𝕩,𝕟​|x^0​k−x0|2.evaluated-atsubscriptMSE𝑘subscript^double-struck-Σ𝑘subscript𝔼conditionalsubscriptdouble-struck-Σ𝑘subscript^double-struck-Σ𝑘𝕩𝕟superscriptsubscript^𝑥0𝑘subscript𝑥02\mathrm{MSE}_{k}|_{\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}_{k}}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{\Sigma}_{k}|\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}_{k},{\mathbb{x}},{\mathbb{n}}}\absolutevalue{\widehat{x}_{0k}-x_{0}}^{2}. (12)

Note that the above ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} and ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} minimize the local MSE, but may not be optimal after fusion. As a result, we treat ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} and ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} as design parameters that can be optimized and refer to ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} as the regularization parameter in the subsequent.

With the linear fusion in (3), the achievable rate of user 00 can be bounded by a standard lower bound R0=log⁡(1+γ0)subscript𝑅01subscript𝛾0R_{0}=\log\left(1+\gamma_{0}\right) based on the worst-case uncorrelated additive noise [27]. Here, γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} is the associated SINR given by

with 𝕣α=[α1∗⋅(𝕣1mmse)T,…,αK∗⋅(𝕣Kmmse)T]T∈ℂNsubscript𝕣𝛼superscript⋅superscriptsubscript𝛼1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝕣mmse1𝑇…⋅superscriptsubscript𝛼𝐾superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝕣mmse𝐾𝑇𝑇superscriptℂ𝑁{\mathbb{r}}_{\alpha}=[\alpha_{1}^{*}\cdot({\mathbb{r}}^{\mathrm{mmse}}_{1})^{T},\ldots,\alpha_{K}^{*}\cdot({\mathbb{r}}^{\mathrm{mmse}}_{K})^{T}]^{T}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}. Next, we determine the optimal fusion coefficients α1,…,αKsubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝐾\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{K} that can maximize the SINR γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} in (15) [2].

III-B Linear Fusion with Optimal Coefficients

The following proposition provides the optimal linear fusion scheme that maximizes the SINR and demonstrates that it also minimizes the MSE for estimating the transmit signal.

Proposition 1.

The optimal coefficients 𝛂T=[α1,…,αK]Tsuperscript𝛂𝑇superscriptsubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝐾𝑇\bm{\alpha}^{T}=[\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{K}]^{T} for maximizing (15) are given by

𝜶opt=c​𝕙~0H​𝔻r​(𝔻rH​(Σ~​Σ~H+𝕎+σ2​𝕀N)​𝔻r)−1,superscript𝜶opt𝑐superscriptsubscript~𝕙0𝐻subscript𝔻𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝔻𝑟𝐻~double-struck-Σsuperscript~double-struck-Σ𝐻𝕎superscript𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑁subscript𝔻𝑟1\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{opt}}=c{\widetilde{{\mathbb{h}}}}_{0}^{H}{\mathbb{D}}_{r}\left({\mathbb{D}}_{r}^{H}\left(\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}}\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}}^{H}+{\mathbb{W}}+\sigma^{2}{\mathbb{I}}_{N}\right){\mathbb{D}}_{r}\right)^{-1}, (16)

where c∈ℂ\{0}𝑐\ℂ0c\in\mathbb{C}\backslash\{0\} and 𝔻r=diag​(𝕣kmmse;k∈[K])subscript𝔻𝑟diagsuperscriptsubscript𝕣𝑘mmse𝑘delimited-[]𝐾{\mathbb{D}}_{r}=\mathrm{diag}({\mathbb{r}}_{k}^{\mathrm{mmse}};k\in[K]). minimize𝜶​MSE|Σ^=𝔼Σ|Σ^,𝕩,𝕟​|∑k=1Kαk​x^0​k−x0|2.evaluated-at𝜶minimizeMSE^double-struck-Σsubscript𝔼conditionaldouble-struck-Σ^double-struck-Σ𝕩𝕟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript^𝑥0𝑘subscript𝑥02\underset{\bm{\alpha}}{\operatorname{minimize}}~{}~{}\mathrm{MSE}|_{\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{\Sigma}|\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}},{\mathbb{x}},{\mathbb{n}}}\absolutevalue{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\widehat{x}_{0k}-x_{0}}^{2}. (17)

Proof: The proof of Proposition 1 is given in Appendix A. ∎

Remark 1.

The optimality of 𝛂optsuperscript𝛂opt\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{opt}} in Proposition 1 holds for any linear receivers, e.g., MRC, and LMMSE is a special case.

Remark 2.

It can be verified that when c=1𝑐1c=1 and 𝛂=𝛂opt𝛂superscript𝛂opt\bm{\alpha}=\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{opt}}, we have MSE|Σ^=(1+γ0)−1=d​log⁡(1+γ0)d​γ0evaluated-atMSE^double-struck-Σsuperscript1subscript𝛾01d1subscript𝛾0dsubscript𝛾0\mathrm{MSE}|_{\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}}=(1+\gamma_{0})^{-1}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\log(1+\gamma_{0})}{\mathrm{d}\gamma_{0}}, which reveals the connection between mutual information and MSE. This relation can be generalized to the case with non-Gaussian signal input [28].

Remark 3.

Proposition 1 shows that the fusion coefficients that maximize the SINR are actually a scaled version of the parameters that minimize MSE.

We will refer to the fusion scheme in Proposition 1 as linear fusion with optimal coefficients (LFOC) in the following. Note that, due to the presence of spatial correlation between different clusters, one cluster cannot determine the off-diagonal elements of ℝj−𝔻R,jsubscriptℝ𝑗subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗{\mathbb{R}}_{j}-{\mathbb{D}}_{R,j} and the channel Σ~~double-struck-Σ\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}} in the feedforward architecture. As a result, to obtain 𝜶optsuperscript𝜶opt\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{opt}}, the CU needs to know the global CSI, which leads to high I/O and computational cost. To reduce the complexity, we proposed two linear fusion schemes in the following.

Based on (16), we can design the suboptimal fusion parameter as

𝜶s​-​opt=𝕙^0H​𝔻r​(𝔻rH​(Σ^​Σ^H+𝔻W+σ2​𝕀N)​𝔻r)−1,superscript𝜶s-optsuperscriptsubscript^𝕙0𝐻subscript𝔻𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝔻𝑟𝐻^double-struck-Σsuperscript^double-struck-Σ𝐻subscript𝔻𝑊superscript𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑁subscript𝔻𝑟1\begin{split}&\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{s}\text{-}\mathrm{opt}}={\widehat{{\mathbb{h}}}}_{0}^{H}{\mathbb{D}}_{r}\left({\mathbb{D}}_{r}^{H}(\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}}^{H}+{\mathbb{D}}_{W}+\sigma^{2}{\mathbb{I}}_{N}){\mathbb{D}}_{r}\right)^{-1},\end{split} (18)

to the CU. Note that the computation and I/O complexity of LFSC is manageable since each parameter in 𝒫ksubscript𝒫𝑘\mathcal{P}_{k} is a vector or a scalar, and the detailed computational complexity is given in Table I. It can be observed the overall complexity of LFSC is significantly reduced compared to CBP.

III-D Linear Fusion with Constant Coefficients

Although LFSC has reduced complexity, it still requires to compute and transmit additional information to the CU. When the number of clusters is very large, the computational complexity, memory requirements, and I/O cost may be very high. To further reduce the complexity, we provide a simple linear fusion scheme with constant coefficients αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}. For example, we can take

αk=1K,k∈[K],formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘1𝐾𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\alpha_{k}=\frac{1}{K},~{}~{}k\in[K], (22)

or more heuristically

αk=NkN,k∈[K].formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑁𝑘𝑁𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\alpha_{k}=\frac{N_{k}}{N},~{}~{}k\in[K]. (23)

We will refer to this scheme as linear fusion with constant coefficients (LFCC) in the following. The complexity of LFCC is also given in Table I which is much lower than that of LFSC. Note that LFCC can be implemented by the FD feedforward architecture [2], where the CU only needs to take the weighted sum of local detection results and does not require any additional intermediate results or processing.

IV Asymptotic SINR Analysis

The expression for the SINR γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} in (37) contains the correlated terms between the channels Σ^^double-struck-Σ\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}} and Σ~~double-struck-Σ\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}}, making it very difficult to analyze. In this section, we will investigate the asymptotic behaviors of γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0}. Specifically, we will show that as the number of antennas and users tend to infinity at the same rate, γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} will converge almost surely, and then derive the deterministic approximations for the SINR of the fusion schemes proposed in Section III. To achieve this, we require the following large-scale system assumptions.

Assumption A.1.

For a given number of clusters K𝐾K, we assume 0<lim infNNkM≤lim supNNkM<+∞0subscriptlimit-infimum𝑁subscript𝑁𝑘𝑀subscriptlimit-supremum𝑁subscript𝑁𝑘𝑀0<\liminf\limits_{N}\frac{N_{k}}{M}\leq\limsup\limits_{N}\frac{N_{k}}{M}<+\infty for each k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K].

Assumption A.2.

Assume

lim supNsupj∈[M]0λM​(ℝj)subscriptlimit-supremum𝑁subscriptsupremum𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0subscript𝜆Msubscriptℝ𝑗\displaystyle\limsup\limits_{N}\sup\limits_{j\in[M]_{0}}\lambda_{\mathrm{M}}({\mathbb{R}}_{j}) <+∞,absent\displaystyle<+\infty, (24a)
lim infNinfj∈[M]0λm​(ℝj)subscriptlimit-infimum𝑁subscriptinfimum𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0subscript𝜆msubscriptℝ𝑗\displaystyle\liminf\limits_{N}\inf\limits_{j\in[M]_{0}}\lambda_{\mathrm{m}}\left({\mathbb{R}}_{j}\right) >0,absent0\displaystyle>0, (24b)

where λM​(𝐑j)subscript𝜆Msubscript𝐑𝑗\lambda_{\mathrm{M}}(\mathbf{R}_{j}) and λm​(𝐑j)subscript𝜆msubscript𝐑𝑗\lambda_{\mathrm{m}}(\mathbf{R}_{j}) denote the largest and smallest eigenvalue of ℝjsubscriptℝ𝑗{\mathbb{R}}_{j}, respectively.

Assumption A.3.

Assume ρk>0subscript𝜌𝑘0\rho_{k}>0 and ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} is Hermitian nonnegative such that lim supNsupk∈[K]‖ℤk‖<+∞subscriptlimit-supremum𝑁subscriptsupremum𝑘delimited-[]𝐾normsubscriptℤ𝑘\limsup\limits_{N}\sup\limits_{k\in[K]}\norm{{\mathbb{Z}}_{k}}<+\infty for each k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K].

A.1 implies that the number of antennas of the k𝑘k-th cluster Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} and the number of users M𝑀M approach infinity at the same rate [2]. For simplicity, we define ck=NkMsubscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑁𝑘𝑀c_{k}=\frac{N_{k}}{M} and use N→c1,…,cK+∞subscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝐾→𝑁N\xrightarrow{c_{1},\ldots,c_{K}}+\infty to represent this asymptotic regime. According to interlacing inequalities [29], A.2 ensures the eigenvalues of the local spatial correlation matrices [ℝj][k,k]subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptℝ𝑗𝑘𝑘[{\mathbb{R}}_{j}]_{[k,k]} are bounded away from 00, which makes 𝕍jsubscript𝕍𝑗{\mathbb{V}}_{j} legal. A.3 implies that the spectral norm of ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} does not diverge to infinity. If A.1 and A.2 hold, (14) satisfies this assumption.

Let γlfocsuperscript𝛾lfoc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfoc}}, γlfscsuperscript𝛾lfsc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfsc}}, and γlfccsuperscript𝛾lfcc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfcc}} denote the SINR with LFOC, LFSC, and LFCC schemes, respectively. The following theorem provides the deterministic approximations for γlfocsuperscript𝛾lfoc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfoc}}, γlfscsuperscript𝛾lfsc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfsc}}, and γlfccsuperscript𝛾lfcc\gamma^{\mathrm{lfcc}}, respectively.

Theorem 1.

Remark 4.

When K=1𝐾1K=1, which means there is only one cluster, γ¯lfocsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}, γ¯lfscsuperscript¯𝛾lfsc\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfsc}}, and γ¯lfccsuperscript¯𝛾lfcc\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfcc}} degenerate to the results with centralized LMMSE [15, 16].

Remark 5.

Under certain conditions, the performance of LFSC approaches that of LFOC. In particular, when 𝚫I=𝚫subscript𝚫𝐼𝚫\bm{\Delta}_{I}=\bm{\Delta}, we have γ¯lfoc=γ¯lfscsuperscript¯𝛾lfocsuperscript¯𝛾lfsc\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}=\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfsc}}. The above condition can be achieved, when the spatial correlations between clusters are negligible, i.e., ℝj=𝔻R,jsubscriptℝ𝑗subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗{\mathbb{R}}_{j}={\mathbb{D}}_{R,j} for each j∈[M]0𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0j\in[M]_{0} or the CSI is perfect, i.e., σ~2=0superscript~𝜎20\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}=0. The equivalence can also be observed from the fact that under the conditions σ~2​ℝj=σ~2​𝔻R,jsuperscript~𝜎2subscriptℝ𝑗superscript~𝜎2subscript𝔻𝑅𝑗\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}{\mathbb{R}}_{j}=\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}{\mathbb{D}}_{R,j} for each j∈[M]0𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]𝑀0j\in[M]_{0}, the LFSC scheme has the same fusion parameters as LFOC, i.e. 𝛂s​-​opt=𝛂optsuperscript𝛂s-optsuperscript𝛂opt\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{s}\text{-}\mathrm{opt}}=\bm{\alpha}^{\mathrm{opt}}.

Remark 6.

When there is no spatial correlation between clusters, the matrix 𝚫𝚫\bm{\Delta} becomes diagonal. Under such circumstances, it can be verified that when 𝛂=C​[(1+[𝕧]1)​[𝕧]1[𝚫]1,1,…,(1+[𝕧]K)​[𝕧]K[𝚫]K,K]𝛂𝐶1subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧1subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧1subscriptdelimited-[]𝚫11…1subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝐾subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝐾subscriptdelimited-[]𝚫𝐾𝐾\bm{\alpha}=C[\frac{(1+[{\mathbb{v}}]_{1})[{\mathbb{v}}]_{1}}{[\bm{\Delta}]_{1,1}},\ldots,\frac{(1+[{\mathbb{v}}]_{K})[{\mathbb{v}}]_{K}}{[\bm{\Delta}]_{K,K}}] with C≠0𝐶0C\neq 0 being an arbitrary constant, we have

γ¯lfoc=γ¯lfsc=γ¯lfcc=∑k=1K[𝕧]k2[𝚫]k,k,superscript¯𝛾lfocsuperscript¯𝛾lfscsuperscript¯𝛾lfccsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝑘2subscriptdelimited-[]𝚫𝑘𝑘\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}=\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfsc}}=\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfcc}}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{[{\mathbb{v}}]_{k}^{2}}{[\bm{\Delta}]_{k,k}}, (27)

which is equal to the sum of the SINRs from all clusters. This is consistent with the conclusion of [2, Theorem 6], which assumes uncorrelated Rayleigh channels and perfect CSI. In addition, [𝕧]ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝑘[{\mathbb{v}}]_{k} and [𝚫]k,ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝚫𝑘𝑘[\bm{\Delta}]_{k,k} are only related to the local spatial correlation, which varies slowly in time. As a result, the fusion coefficients for LFCC can be set as αk=(1+[𝕧]k)​[𝕧]k[𝚫]k,ksubscript𝛼𝑘1subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]𝕧𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]𝚫𝑘𝑘\alpha_{k}=\frac{(1+[{\mathbb{v}}]_{k})[{\mathbb{v}}]_{k}}{[\bm{\Delta}]_{k,k}} to achieve the asymptotically optimal performance.

IV-A2 Regularization Parameter

Remark 7.

We can observe that the optimal parameter 𝛒Koptsuperscriptsubscript𝛒𝐾opt\bm{\rho}_{K}^{\mathrm{opt}} that maximizes the SINR is identical to that achieving the minimal local MSE as derived in Section III-A. This can be intuitively obtained from (28a) where the SINR γ¯lfocsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}} is the sum of the SINRs of all clusters.

IV-A3 Antenna Partitioning Strategy

The following corollary shows the impact of the parameter 𝕔Ksubscript𝕔𝐾{\mathbb{c}}_{K}.

where 𝕔K,m=[c¯,…,c¯]Tsubscript𝕔𝐾msuperscript¯𝑐…¯𝑐𝑇{\mathbb{c}}_{K,\mathrm{m}}=[\overline{c},\ldots,\overline{c}]^{T}, 𝕔K,M=[K​c¯,0,…,0]Tsubscript𝕔𝐾Msuperscript𝐾¯𝑐0…0𝑇{\mathbb{c}}_{K,\mathrm{M}}=[K\overline{c},0,\ldots,0]^{T}, and c¯=1K​∑k=1Kck¯𝑐1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑐𝑘\overline{c}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}c_{k}.

Proof: The proof of Corollary 3 is given in Appendix F. ∎

Remark 8.

Inequalities (​32​)italic-(32italic-)\eqref{Eq_gamma_c_M} and (33) imply that when the regularization parameter 𝛒Ksubscript𝛒𝐾\bm{\rho}_{K} is within a certain range, i.e., σ2M≤asuperscript𝜎2𝑀𝑎\frac{\sigma^{2}}{M}\leq a, the system achieves the maximum SINR when the receive antennas are concentrated in one cluster, i.e., the centralized scheme. On the other side, when the antennas are equally partitioned, the system achieves the lowest SINR. This finding aligns with the conclusions in [2, Lemma 7, Lemma 8]. Note that [2] considers a given parameter 𝛒Ksubscript𝛒𝐾\bm{\rho}_{K} with perfect CSI, but Corollary 3 provides the range for 𝛒Ksubscript𝛒𝐾\bm{\rho}_{K} with imperfect CSI.

Remark 9.

It can be observed that the optimal regularization parameter 𝛒Koptsubscriptsuperscript𝛒opt𝐾\bm{\rho}^{\mathrm{opt}}_{K} in Corollary 2 is within the range such that (​32​)italic-(32italic-)\eqref{Eq_gamma_c_M} and (33) hold.

IV-A4 Number of Clusters

Corollary 3 compares different antenna partitioning strategies with a fixed number of clusters K𝐾K. Another interesting question to investigate is how the number of clusters K𝐾K affects the SINR. The following corollary demonstrates this impact.

Corollary 4.

Assume the same conditions as Corollary 1 and denote 𝛒K=[ac1,…,acK]Tsubscript𝛒𝐾superscript𝑎subscript𝑐1…𝑎subscript𝑐𝐾𝑇\bm{\rho}_{K}=[\frac{a}{c_{1}},\ldots,\frac{a}{c_{K}}]^{T}. For any σ2M≤asuperscript𝜎2𝑀𝑎\frac{\sigma^{2}}{M}\leq a, we have

γ¯Klfoc​(𝝆K,𝕔K,m)≥γ¯K+1lfoc​(𝝆K+1,𝕔K+1,m).subscriptsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc𝐾subscript𝝆𝐾subscript𝕔𝐾msubscriptsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc𝐾1subscript𝝆𝐾1subscript𝕔𝐾1m\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}_{K}(\bm{\rho}_{K},{\mathbb{c}}_{K,\mathrm{m}})\geq\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}_{K+1}(\bm{\rho}_{K+1},{\mathbb{c}}_{K+1,\mathrm{m}}). (34)

Proof: The proof of Corollary 4 is given in Appendix G. ∎

Remark 10.

Since the total number of receive antennas N𝑁N is fixed, Corollary 4 indicates that as the number of clusters increases, the SINR will monotonically decrease.

Remark 11.

It can be verified from the proof of Corollary 4 that

γ¯Klfoc​(𝝆K,𝕔K,m)≥N(σ2+M)​(σ~2+1)+σ~2,subscriptsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc𝐾subscript𝝆𝐾subscript𝕔𝐾m𝑁superscript𝜎2𝑀superscript~𝜎21superscript~𝜎2\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}_{K}(\bm{\rho}_{K},{\mathbb{c}}_{K,\mathrm{m}})\geq\frac{N}{(\sigma^{2}+M)(\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}+1)+\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}}, (35)

and the equality holds when K→+∞→𝐾K\rightarrow+\infty, which is not achievable since K≤N𝐾𝑁K\leq N. From Corollary 3, we know that the equal antenna partitioning strategy has the worst performance. Therefore, for decentralized LMMSE receivers, the SINR is strictly lower bounded by the right hand side (RHS) of (35). When the numbers of antennas and users are large, this lower bound is approximately NM𝑁𝑀\frac{N}{M}.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we will verify the accuracy of the theoretical results in Sections IV. We will also demonstrate the impact of several key system parameters over i.i.d. channels, including the regularization parameter, antenna partitioning strategy, and the number of clusters. For simplicity, we use the notation 𝒩K=(N1,…,NK)subscript𝒩𝐾subscript𝑁1…subscript𝑁𝐾\mathcal{N}_{K}=(N_{1},\ldots,N_{K}) to denote the antenna partitioning strategy. The Monte Carlo (MC) simulation results were obtained from 5000 realizations and are illustrated by markers in all figures.

V-A Correlated Channels

We consider a uniform linear array of antennas at the BS. The (m,n)𝑚𝑛(m,n)-th entry of the spatial correlation matrix at BS is modeled as [30, 31]

[𝐂​(η,δ,ds)]m,n=∫−18018012​π​δ2​e2​π​ȷ​ds​(m−n)​sin⁡(π​ϕ180)−(ϕ−η)22​δ2​dϕ.subscriptdelimited-[]𝐂𝜂𝛿subscript𝑑𝑠𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript18018012𝜋superscript𝛿2superscript𝑒2𝜋italic-ȷsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑚𝑛𝜋italic-ϕ180superscriptitalic-ϕ𝜂22superscript𝛿2differential-ditalic-ϕ\begin{split}&\left[\mathbf{C}(\eta,\delta,d_{s})\right]_{m,n}\\ &=\int_{-180}^{180}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\delta^{2}}}e^{2\pi\jmath d_{s}(m-n)\sin(\frac{\pi\phi}{180})-\frac{(\phi-\eta)^{2}}{2\delta^{2}}}\mathrm{d}\phi.\end{split} (36)

Here, dssubscript𝑑𝑠d_{s} and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi denote the receive antenna spacing and angular spread, respectively, η𝜂\eta represents the mean angle, and δ𝛿\delta denotes the root-mean-square angle spread. In the simulation, we set ℝj=ℂ​(ηj,δj,1)subscriptℝ𝑗ℂsubscript𝜂𝑗subscript𝛿𝑗1{\mathbb{R}}_{j}={\mathbb{C}}(\eta_{j},\delta_{j},1) with ηj=(j180​M)∘subscript𝜂𝑗superscript𝑗180𝑀\eta_{j}=(\frac{j}{180M})^{\circ} and δj=10∘+(jM​10)∘subscript𝛿𝑗superscript10superscript𝑗𝑀10\delta_{j}=10^{\circ}+(\frac{j}{M10})^{\circ}. The parameter ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} is set as ρk=σ2Nksubscript𝜌𝑘superscript𝜎2subscript𝑁𝑘\rho_{k}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N_{k}} and ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} is set according to (14) for each k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K].

Approximation of SINR: Fig. 2 illustrates the SINR with different linear fusion schemes. The system dimensions are set as N=32𝑁32N=32, M=12𝑀12M=12, K=2𝐾2K=2, and 𝒩2=(10,22)subscript𝒩21022\mathcal{N}_{2}=(10,22). The red line and the black dotted line represent the results of centralized LMMSE and LFCC with 𝜶=[0.5,0.5]T𝜶superscript0.50.5𝑇\bm{\alpha}=[0.5,0.5]^{T}, respectively. By comparing the results with MC simulations, we can observe that the approximation results in Theorem 1 are accurate. By comparing the results of LFSC and LFOC, it can be observed that LFSC is highly efficient. Furthermore, Fig. 2 shows that when the antenna partition is unbalanced, using LFCC will lead to performance degradation.

Impact of Fusion Coefficients: Fig. 3 shows the impact of the fusion coefficients with different antenna partitioning strategies. The system dimensions are set as N=40𝑁40N=40, M=15𝑀15M=15, and K=2𝐾2K=2. The signal and training SNR are both set as 303030 dB. It can be observed that when antennas are uniformly allocated to different clusters, i.e., 𝒩2=(20,20)subscript𝒩22020\mathcal{N}_{2}=(20,20), SINR is not sensitive to the value of 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha}, but the maximum SINR is lower than that with unbalanced antenna partitioning. This observation for correlated channels is consistent with the conclusion for i.i.d. channels in Corollary 3. Moreover, as the number of antennas in a cluster increases, the corresponding linear fusion weights should also increase.

V-B I.I.D. Channels

In the experiment, the training and signal SNR are both 30 dB, and the parameter ℤksubscriptℤ𝑘{\mathbb{Z}}_{k} is set according to (​14​)italic-(14italic-)\eqref{Eq_MMSE_parameters_Z} for each k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K].

Optimal Regularization Parameter: Fig. 4 depicts the impact of 𝝆Ksubscript𝝆𝐾\bm{\rho}_{K} on the SINR with i.i.d. channels. The system dimensions are set as N=72𝑁72N=72 and M=40𝑀40M=40. The parameter 𝝆Ksubscript𝝆𝐾\bm{\rho}_{K} is of the form 𝝆K=[ρN1,…,ρNK]Tsubscript𝝆𝐾superscript𝜌subscript𝑁1…𝜌subscript𝑁𝐾𝑇\bm{\rho}_{K}=[\frac{\rho}{N_{1}},\ldots,\frac{\rho}{N_{K}}]^{T}. It can be observed that SINR is not sensitive to ρ𝜌\rho. Significant performance loss is only observed when ρ𝜌\rho is very large. Furthermore, according to Corollary 2, the theoretical optimal parameter 𝝆Koptsuperscriptsubscript𝝆𝐾opt\bm{\rho}_{K}^{\mathrm{opt}} should be 𝝆Kopt=(−30​d​B)⋅[1N1,…,1N1]Tsuperscriptsubscript𝝆𝐾opt⋅30dBsuperscript1subscript𝑁1…1subscript𝑁1𝑇\bm{\rho}_{K}^{\mathrm{opt}}=(-30\mathrm{dB})\cdot[\frac{1}{N_{1}},\ldots,\frac{1}{N_{1}}]^{T}. The optimal value ρopt=−30superscript𝜌opt30\rho^{\mathrm{opt}}=-30 dB shown in the figure obtained by the exhausted search validates the accuracy of Corollary 2.

Impact of Antenna Partitioning Strategy: In Fig. 5, we plot the SINR for different antenna partitioning strategies with different numbers of users. The parameters are set as N=120𝑁120N=120, K=2𝐾2K=2, and ρk=σ2Nksubscript𝜌𝑘superscript𝜎2subscript𝑁𝑘\rho_{k}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N_{k}}. It is observed that when clusters are of equal size, the SINR is the lowest, which agrees with Corollary 3. Furthermore, as the number of users increases, the performance degradation with uniform antenna partitioning becomes more obvious.

Impact of Number of Clusters: In Fig. 6, we plot the SINR for different numbers of clusters K𝐾K where antennas are almost equally allocated with 𝒩K=(⌊NK⌋,⌊NK⌋,…,N−(K−1)​⌊NK⌋)subscript𝒩𝐾𝑁𝐾𝑁𝐾…𝑁𝐾1𝑁𝐾\mathcal{N}_{K}=(\lfloor\frac{N}{K}\rfloor,\lfloor\frac{N}{K}\rfloor,\ldots,N-(K-1)\lfloor\frac{N}{K}\rfloor). The parameters are set as M=40𝑀40M=40 and ρk=σ2Nksubscript𝜌𝑘superscript𝜎2subscript𝑁𝑘\rho_{k}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N_{k}}. It can be observed that as the number of clusters increases, the SINR decreases monotonically and is lower bounded by (35), which is shown by the dashed lines. This validates Corollary 4.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we considered the decentralized MIMO systems with LMMSE receivers and imperfect CSI. It was shown that with DBP, the linear fusion coefficients that maximize the receive SINR also minimize the MSE for estimating the transmit signal. To reduce the complexity, we further proposed two linear fusion schemes and derived the deterministic approximations of the SINR with imperfect CSI and general spatial correlations. Based on the results, we investigated the optimal LMMSE regularization parameters, optimal antenna partitioning strategies, and the impact of the number of clusters. It was shown that with i.i.d. channels, the SINR is minimized when the clusters are of equal size. Conversely, the optimal performance is achieved when antennas are mostly unbalanced distributed, i.e., all antennas are allocated to a single cluster. We also proved that as the number of clusters increases, the SINR monotonically decreases.

From the perspective of RMT, we investigated the asymptotic convergence properties of the resolvent for the covariance matrix with generally correlated columns and its related functions. These results can be utilized for the second-order SINR analysis, e.g., the outage probability, and also be applied to downlink scenarios, e.g., the analysis of RZF.

Appendix C Useful Results

C-A Matrix Inversion Lemma

Lemma 1.

[21, Lemma 1]: Let 𝕄∈ℂN×N𝕄superscriptℂ𝑁𝑁{\mathbb{M}}\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times N} be an invertible matrix, 𝕞∈ℂN𝕞superscriptℂ𝑁{\mathbb{m}}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}, and a∈ℂ𝑎ℂa\in\mathbb{C}. If 1+a​𝕞H​𝕄−1​𝕞≠01𝑎superscript𝕞𝐻superscript𝕄1𝕞01+a{\mathbb{m}}^{H}{\mathbb{M}}^{-1}{\mathbb{m}}\neq 0, we have

(51)

C-C Convergence of Random Matrices

The SINR involves terms associated with random matrices Σ^^double-struck-Σ\widehat{\mathbb{\Sigma}} and Σ~~double-struck-Σ\widetilde{\mathbb{\Sigma}} whose columns are generally correlated. This makes the evaluation of the SINR very challenging. In the following, we introduce a more general setting and provide the relevant results, which can be utilized to prove Theorem 1.

We next introduce the stochastic equivalent notation.

Definition 1.

(Stochastic Equivalent) For random sequence (XN)N≥1subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑁𝑁1(X_{N})_{N\geq 1} and deterministic sequence (X¯N)N≥1subscriptsubscript¯𝑋𝑁𝑁1(\overline{X}_{N})_{N\geq 1}, we use XN≍lX¯Nsubscriptasymptotically-equals𝑙subscript𝑋𝑁subscript¯𝑋𝑁X_{N}{\asymp}_{l}\overline{X}_{N} to denote

The following lemma gives the stochastic equivalents for the functions in Table II.

Lemma 3.

Proof: The proof of Lemma 3 is given in Appendix D. ∎

Appendix D Proof of Lemma 3

The proof relies on Gaussian tools [34, 35, 36, 16, 37], which consist of the integration by parts formula [35, Eq. (17)] and the Poincaré-Nash inequality [35, Eq. (18)]. According to the Poincaré–Nash inequality, the variance of functions defined in Table II can be proved of order 𝒪​(1)𝒪1{\mathcal{O}}(1) (See [32, Lemma 9] for the case of ϝksubscriptitalic-ϝ𝑘\digamma_{k} and the proof of other functions are similar). As a result, for given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, we have

∑N=1+∞ℙ​(|𝒳−𝔼​𝒳|N≥ϵ)≤∑N=1+∞Var​(𝒳)ϵ2​N2<+∞,superscriptsubscript𝑁1ℙ𝒳𝔼𝒳𝑁italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑁1Var𝒳superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝑁2\begin{split}&\sum_{N=1}^{+\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{\absolutevalue{\mathcal{X}-\mathbb{E}\mathcal{X}}}{N}\geq\epsilon\right)\leq\sum_{N=1}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{Var}(\mathcal{X})}{\epsilon^{2}N^{2}}{<}+\infty,\end{split} (67)

where 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} can be any function in Table II. Thus, according to Borel–Cantelli lemma, we have

𝒳−𝔼​𝒳N→N→c1,…,cK+∞a.s.0.\frac{\mathcal{X}-\mathbb{E}\mathcal{X}}{N}\xrightarrow[N\xrightarrow{c_{1},\ldots,c_{K}}+\infty]{a.s.}0. (68)

Therefore, to show the stochastic equivalence, we only need to evaluate the means of functions in Table II.

Hence, we build the relation between ℚksubscriptℚ𝑘{\mathbb{Q}}_{k} and Θα,ksubscriptdouble-struck-Θ𝛼𝑘\mathbb{\Theta}_{\alpha,k}.

To establish the relationship between Θα,ksubscriptdouble-struck-Θ𝛼𝑘\mathbb{\Theta}_{\alpha,k} and Θksubscriptdouble-struck-Θ𝑘\mathbb{\Theta}_{k}, we take the difference between Tr[Ωj][k,k]Θα,k\Tr[\mathbb{\Omega}_{j}]_{[k,k]}\mathbb{\Theta}_{\alpha,k} and δj​ksubscript𝛿𝑗𝑘\delta_{jk} for each j∈[M]𝑗delimited-[]𝑀j\in[M]. Following the same procedure as in the proof of [32, Proposition 3], we can show that |Tr⁡𝓐​Θk−Tr⁡𝓐​Θα,k|=𝒪​(N−12),trace𝓐subscriptdouble-struck-Θ𝑘trace𝓐subscriptdouble-struck-Θ𝛼𝑘𝒪superscript𝑁12\absolutevalue{\Tr\bm{\mathcal{A}}\mathbb{\Theta}_{k}-\Tr\bm{\mathcal{A}}\mathbb{\Theta}_{\alpha,k}}={\mathcal{O}}(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}), which concludes (61).

Appendix G Proof of Corollary 4

In this proof, we will reuse the notations in Appendix F. Moreover, we define csum=NMsubscript𝑐sum𝑁𝑀c_{\mathrm{sum}}=\frac{N}{M}. By (96), the SINR is given by

Since f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) is monotonically increasing w.r.t. x𝑥x, δ¯Ksubscript¯𝛿𝐾\overline{\delta}_{K} monotonically decreases w.r.t. K𝐾K. Additionally, (103) implies

K​δ¯K=csumA+11+δ¯K,𝐾subscript¯𝛿𝐾subscript𝑐sum𝐴11subscript¯𝛿𝐾K\overline{\delta}_{K}=\frac{c_{\mathrm{sum}}}{A+\frac{1}{1+\overline{\delta}_{K}}}, (104)

which further indicates that K​δ¯K𝐾subscript¯𝛿𝐾K\overline{\delta}_{K} is also monotonically decreasing. Since a≥σ2M𝑎superscript𝜎2𝑀a\geq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{M}, we have B≤0𝐵0B\leq 0 and

γ¯Klfoc​(𝝆K,𝕔K,m)≥(K+1)​δ¯K+11+BA+1(1+δ¯K)2≥(K+1)​δ¯K+11+BA+1(1+δ¯K+1)2=γ¯K+1lfoc​(𝝆K+1,𝕔K+1,m),subscriptsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc𝐾subscript𝝆𝐾subscript𝕔𝐾m𝐾1subscript¯𝛿𝐾11𝐵𝐴1superscript1subscript¯𝛿𝐾2𝐾1subscript¯𝛿𝐾11𝐵𝐴1superscript1subscript¯𝛿𝐾12subscriptsuperscript¯𝛾lfoc𝐾1subscript𝝆𝐾1subscript𝕔𝐾1m\begin{split}&\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}_{K}(\bm{\rho}_{K},{\mathbb{c}}_{K,\mathrm{m}})\geq\frac{(K+1)\overline{\delta}_{K+1}}{1+\frac{B}{A+\frac{1}{(1+\overline{\delta}_{K})^{2}}}}\\ &\geq\frac{(K+1)\overline{\delta}_{K+1}}{1+\frac{B}{A+\frac{1}{(1+\overline{\delta}_{K+1})^{2}}}}=\overline{\gamma}^{\mathrm{lfoc}}_{K+1}(\bm{\rho}_{K+1},{\mathbb{c}}_{K+1,\mathrm{m}}),\end{split} (105)

which conclude (34). ∎
